title: What is your least favorite song from your favorite musical? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have to go with “Hundreds of Stories” from In The Heights. But Jordan! you say. Isn’t Hamilton your favorite musical? Meh. Not right now. Don’t get me wrong—I love Hamilton. It’s a brilliant musical, but I think I wore myself out on it. It’s all I listened to for the year surrounding when I saw it, so… I need a break. But I just can’t stay away from LMM. In The Heights. Great show. You can’t go wrong with LMM/Quiara Hudes. But “Hundreds of Stories” has probably one of the worst introductions of exposition I’ve ever heard. USNAVIAbuela, I don't know how I can keep it together ABUELA CLAUDIARemember the story of your nameIt was engraved on a passing ship on the day your family cameYou father said "Usnavi"That's what we'll name the baby USNAVIIt really said "US Navy," but heyI worked with what they gave me okay ABUELA CLAUDIAThey'd be so proud of you today It comes out of nowhere. Usnavi’s talking about his parents, about how hard it was to lose them and how he doesn’t know what he’s going to do, and Abuela comes out with… that. “Remember how your parents named you?” Like, yeah, I’m sure Usnavi does remember how his parents named him. I get that introducing a fact which everyone onstage knows is one of the hardest things to execute well, but LMM… did not execute it well. It hurts my ears whenever I hear it because it’s so abrupt. I get why that fact needs to be there. I get why it’s important. I just wish it’d been introduced a little better. Besides that, this song just never meshed with me. It’s fine, I guess. It just doesn’t do it for me. Abuela’s also not my favorite character (is that bad? I don’t know) so I think a song that’s mostly her isn’t my cup o’ tea. I take that back. I love “Paciencia Y Ve”. I think it’s just this song I don’t like.  I feel like I can’t answer this without also giving my least favorite Hamilton song. It’s a struggle, because I don’t like Pippa Soo in this show, nor do I like Chris Jackson (love him in In The Heights, though). It’s hard to pick a least favorite song separate of the actors. I probably have to give it to Who Lives, Who Dies, Who Tells Your Story. It’s just… bland. I get why LMM ended it on Eliza’s story, but I don’t really care about Eliza. Her character was not super compelling in the show so having a whole song about her and her story was kind of just, cool, whatever, who cares. I almost wish he would’ve ended it on The World Was Wide Enough. What a powerful ending. It would’ve dropped the theme that’s brought through in the actual last song, but damn… Ending on the line “The world was wide enough for both Hamilton and me.” That’s killer. Even then, though, it’s not like I hate this song. It’s fine. I struggled with even picking one because I really do love the vast majority of the songs in the show. Even my least favorites are just songs I like less than the others. So, take that as you will.

I gotta go with “Turning” from Les Miserables. Let me elaborate: I love Les Miz. I know the score by heart and my friends joke that I know each bar personally. But any time I see the show or listen to the various recordings, I wonder why this number wasn’t cut from a show that is already very long and how it survived all efforts to cut the runtime down (which lost some other bits I generally like). Don’t get me wrong, the song is pretty, but nothing that stands out; it also provides a new perspective on the whole revolution plot. But I feel it just stalls the show and is simply not needed. We just had the whole barricade scene, we had the sewers and Javert’s suicide. And now we cut to people talking about the failed revolution instead of seeing what happened to the characters we care about? Seems redundant and actually makes me lose interest in the song every time. Removing “Turning” and progressing immediately to “Empty Chairs” would - in my opinion - be the better option as it gets us into the last bit of the story faster.

Least favorite song from a musical? (This question has been changed from "least favorite song by your favorite singer.) Separating the songs that I don't like because I didn't like the musical in the first place,and having to pick a favorite musical? Well, let's start there. My two favorite musicals are "Cabaret" and "A Chorus Line." I like them because they are the least contrived. I don't think there is a bad song in "A Chorus Line." And I had to work to find one in "Cabaret." But there's an instrumental number called "Sitting Pretty" that neither adds to the theme of the rise of Nazi power nor to the secondary purpose of promoting Liza Minelli's fabulous performance. It's just filler, and not even great jazz.

Okay, so this is such a hard one because 1) It’s hard to pick a favorite and 2) It’s hard to pick a least favorite. So I’ll just give a few. Spring Awakening - Song of Purple Summer. It’s a pretty song, and I love it by itself, but within the musical itself… I don’t like it.Next to Normal - I Dreamed a Dance. It’s just not my cup of tea.Dear Evan Hansen - To Break in a Glove. This one is just kind of meh for me.Hamilton - Farmer Refuted. While this is a funny song, I just don’t like it that much.Rent - I Should Tell You. I think it’s just a little blah.And that’s about all I have.

Let me put it down to my top 9 musicals, because choosing between them is hard, and my opinion changes daily. The Guy Who Didn’t Like Musicals- ‘Not Your Seed’ (a controversial pick amongst the fandom) Hairspray- ‘(You’re) Timeless to Me’ Kinky Boots- ‘Hold me in your Heart’ Trail to Oregon- ‘When the World’s At Stake’ Spies are Forever- ‘Spy Dance’ Hamilton- ‘Best of Wives, Best of Women’ In the Heights- ‘Hundreds of Stories’ A Very Potter Musical- ‘Pigfarts’ A Very Potter Sequel- ‘Stutter’ Wicked- ‘A Sentimental man’ The Drowsy Chaperone- ‘As We Stumble Along’

Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat is my favorite. Every song is awesome but “Any Dream will Do” It adds nothing to the plot. It’s just a nice song but it is a standard Broadway ballad.  It could be cut and made for a tighter production.

I always felt the title track from the animated film Beauty and the Beast was wasted using Angela Lansbery (Mrs. Potts) instead of Jerry Orbach (Lumiere). Lumiere had already had a great number with Be Our Guest, so the director may have wanted to mix it up with Mrs. Potts. Even on my first viewing of the film I felt very strongly that Lumiere would've handled that song about a thousand times better.

The love montage in Les Misérables. When it first opened, there were three consecutive lovey dovey ballads in a row there. It was cut down but could stand being cut further. All I Ask of You from Phantom. It goes on far too long and doesn’t advance the plot sufficiently. It could be half the length.
From The Music Man (1962 film) - Wikipedia  Every other song kind of ties into the plot, but this one. I did, however, like the Family Guy version
